heading: 📖 Introduction
text: Welcome use genekitr!book tutorial gene information query, ID conversion, enrichment analysis, publication-level plotting. new R, worry, set enough example codes guide book. reading book, plot figures based analysis result.

heading: 📚 Content
text: Part 1 (Search Information) introduces search gene metadata PubMed papers.Part 2 (ID Conversion) describes ID conversion among symbol & alias, NCBI Entrez, Ensembl, Uniprot microarray probe.Part 3 (Enrichment Analysis) describes two widely used functional enrichment methods -representation analysis (ORA) functional class scoring (FCS).Part 4 (Plotting) includes 14 GO plots, 7 KEGG plots, 5 GSEA plots, 2 Venn plots, 1 Volcano plot.

heading: ❤️ Welcome to contribute
text: Book source code https://github.com/GangLiLab/book_genekitr.get ideas issues, please feel free post feedback.

heading: 1 Search gene metadata
text: users groups genes check names, location, GC content etc., can use genInfo() function quickly check.

heading: 1.1 Supported organisms
text: Support 196 vertebrate species, 120 plant species 2 bacteria species. data --date.user select organism name latin_short_name column. common name acceptable popular research species (e.g., human, mouse, rat, fly, zebrafish, worm, chicken). Take human example; official Latin short name “happens,” hg," “hsa,” “hs,” “human” also acceptable.
code:
# install.packages('DT')
library(genekitr)
DT::datatable(ensOrg_name, options = list(pageLength = 10))

heading: 1.2 Basic usage
text: three arguments genInfo():id: gene id (symbol, Entrez Ensembl) protein idid: gene id (symbol, Entrez Ensembl) protein idorg: organism name, default humanorg: organism name, default humanunique: TRUE FALSE. Commonly, one gene many types matched records. example, human HBD gene three matched Entrez IDs: 3045, 85349, 100187828. TRUE, return one--one match result minimal NAs.unique: TRUE FALSE. Commonly, one gene many types matched records. example, human HBD gene three matched Entrez IDs: 3045, 85349, 100187828. TRUE, return one--one match result minimal NAs.one--many mapping happens user wants get unique match, ID maximum information return (minimum NAs).
code:
id <- "HBD"
uniq_info <- genInfo(id, org = 'hs', unique = TRUE)
uniq_info[1:4]##   input_id symbol  entrezid         ensembl
## 1      HBD    HBD 100187828 ENSG00000223609
all_info <- genInfo(id, org = 'hs', unique = FALSE)
all_info[1:4]##   input_id symbol  entrezid         ensembl
## 1      HBD    HBD 100187828 ENSG00000223609
## 2      HBD KRT87P     85349 ENSG00000135477
colnames(all_info)##  [1] "input_id"         "symbol"           "entrezid"         "ensembl"          "uniprot"         
##  [6] "chr"              "start"            "end"              "width"            "strand"          
## [11] "gene_name"        "ncbi_alias"       "ensembl_alias"    "gc_content"       "gene_biotype"    
## [16] "transcript_count" "hgnc_id"          "omim"             "ccds"             "reactome"        
## [21] "ucsc"             "mirbase_id"

heading: 1.3.1 Feature1: keep input id order
text: genInfo result strictly keep input order even unrecognized ids.user gives misspelled gene id id belong organism, result provide columns NA.
code:
id <- c("MCM10", "CDC20", "S100A9", 
        "FAKEID", "TP53", "HBD", "NUDT10")
# for human id, no need to input the org argument
info <- genInfo(id)
identical(id, unique(info$input_id))## [1] TRUE
head(info,3)##   input_id symbol entrezid         ensembl                uniprot chr     start       end width
## 1    MCM10  MCM10    55388 ENSG00000065328 Q7L590; Q5T670; C9J600  10  13161558  13211110 49553
## 2    CDC20  CDC20      991 ENSG00000117399                 Q12834   1  43358981  43363203  4223
## 3   S100A9 S100A9     6280 ENSG00000163220                 P06702   1 153357854 153361023  3170
##   strand                                                   gene_name
## 1      1 minichromosome maintenance 10 replication initiation factor
## 2      1                                      cell division cycle 20
## 3      1                             S100 calcium binding protein A9

heading: 1.3.2 Feature2: recognize both gene symbol and alias
text: Many common gene names gene alias, many programs accept gene symbols cause gene information lost. example, “BCC7” alias “TP53”, “PD1” three aliases: “PDCD1”, “SNCA” “SPATA2”.
code:
id <- c("BCC7","PD1")
genInfo(id)[1:4]##   input_id symbol entrezid         ensembl
## 1     BCC7   TP53     7157 ENSG00000141510
## 2      PD1  PDCD1     5133 ENSG00000188389
## 3      PD1  PDCD1     5133 ENSG00000276977
## 4      PD1   SNCA     6622 ENSG00000145335
## 5      PD1 SPATA2     9825 ENSG00000158480

heading: 1.3.3 Feature3: count organism gene types
text: , need calculate symbols one--many matched types. course, many genes NA biotypes uncategorized.
code:
uniq_symbol <- genInfo(org = 'hs') %>% 
  dplyr::filter(!is.na(gene_biotype)) %>% 
  dplyr::distinct(symbol,.keep_all = T) 

uniq_symbol %>%  {table(.$gene_biotype)}## 
##                          IG_C_gene                    IG_C_pseudogene 
##                                 14                                  8 
##                          IG_D_gene                          IG_J_gene 
##                                 37                                 18 
##                    IG_J_pseudogene                          IG_V_gene 
##                                  3                                144 
##                    IG_V_pseudogene                             lncRNA 
##                                185                               6096 
##                              miRNA                           misc_RNA 
##                               1852                               1034 
##                            Mt_rRNA                            Mt_tRNA 
##                                  2                                 23 
##             polymorphic_pseudogene               processed_pseudogene 
##                                 46                               7196 
##                     protein_coding                           ribozyme 
##                              19578                                  4 
##                               rRNA                    rRNA_pseudogene 
##                                 46                                496 
##                             scaRNA                              scRNA 
##                                 18                                  1 
##                             snoRNA                              snRNA 
##                                437                               1834 
##                               sRNA                                TEC 
##                                  1                                 28 
##                          TR_C_gene                          TR_D_gene 
##                                  7                                  4 
##                          TR_J_gene                    TR_J_pseudogene 
##                                 79                                  4 
##                          TR_V_gene                    TR_V_pseudogene 
##                                107                                 33 
##   transcribed_processed_pseudogene     transcribed_unitary_pseudogene 
##                                353                                130 
## transcribed_unprocessed_pseudogene    translated_processed_pseudogene 
##                                776                                  2 
##  translated_unprocessed_pseudogene                 unitary_pseudogene 
##                                  2                                 78 
##             unprocessed_pseudogene 
##                               1703

heading: 1.3.4 Feature4: extract specific biotype genes
text: want get human protein-coding genes:Compare HGNC data:Check missing gene names result:seems gene “ABTB3” recently modified, GeneCards also shows result.look EntrezID 121551, also known “BTBD11” matched Ensembl data: ENSG00000151136So reason mismatch --sync extensive database Ensembl NCBI.
code:
hg_pro_gene <- uniq_symbol %>% 
  dplyr::filter(gene_biotype == 'protein_coding') %>% 
  dplyr::pull(symbol) 
  
length(hg_pro_gene)## [1] 19578
hgnc_data <- rio::import('http://ftp.ebi.ac.uk/pub/databases/genenames/hgnc/tsv/locus_types/gene_with_protein_product.txt') 
hgnc_symbol <- hgnc_data$symbol
plotVenn(list(genekitr_symbol = hg_pro_gene,
              hgnc_symbol = hgnc_symbol))
check_genes <- head(hgnc_symbol[!hgnc_symbol%in%hg_pro_gene],3)
hgnc_data %>% dplyr::filter(symbol %in% check_genes) %>% 
  dplyr::select(symbol,date_approved_reserved,date_symbol_changed,
                entrez_id)##   symbol date_approved_reserved date_symbol_changed entrez_id
## 1  ABTB3             2003-12-15          2022-05-13    121551
## 2 ADGRF2             2002-11-26          2015-03-03    222611
## 3  AKR7L             2008-12-09                <NA>    246181
genInfo('121551')[1:3]##   input_id         ensembl symbol
## 1   121551 ENSG00000151136 BTBD11

heading: 2 Search PubMed records
text:
getPubmed function use europepmc easily get PubMed records searching paper abstract.user needs input term argument; supplement information, keys parameter available.example, want check papers genes “Tp53”, “Brca1,” “Tet2” mouse stem cells, write codes like :NOTICE:
minor update made version 0.8.6 . Argument keys replaced add_term easy understanding, num parameter added specify number returned records.
code:
term <- c("Tp53","Brca1","Tet2")
keys <- c('stem cell','mouse')
l <- getPubmed(term,keys)
names(l)## [1] "Tp53"  "Brca1" "Tet2"
head(l$Tp53,5)## # A tibble: 5 × 28
##   id        source pmid     pmcid    doi   title authorString journalTitle issue journalVolume pubYear
##   <chr>     <chr>  <chr>    <chr>    <chr> <chr> <chr>        <chr>        <chr> <chr>         <chr>  
## 1 35409174  MED    35409174 PMC8998… 10.3… "Enh… Gringmuth M… Int J Mol S… 7     23            2022   
## 2 PPR467733 PPR    <NA>     <NA>     10.1… "Bia… Ohno T, Aka… <NA>         <NA>  <NA>          2022   
## 3 35435331  MED    35435331 <NA>     10.1… "Ide… Thirouard L… Adv Sci (We… <NA>  <NA>          2022   
## 4 35536873  MED    35536873 <NA>     10.1… "Com… Liu T, Zhao… Cancer Res   <NA>  <NA>          2022   
## 5 PPR483807 PPR    <NA>     <NA>     10.2… "Nic… Yu Z, Tong … <NA>         <NA>  <NA>          2022   
## # … with 17 more variables: journalIssn <chr>, pageInfo <chr>, pubType <chr>, isOpenAccess <chr>,
## #   inEPMC <chr>, inPMC <chr>, hasPDF <chr>, hasBook <chr>, hasSuppl <chr>, citedByCount <int>,
## #   hasReferences <chr>, hasTextMinedTerms <chr>, hasDbCrossReferences <chr>, hasLabsLinks <chr>,
## #   hasTMAccessionNumbers <chr>, firstIndexDate <chr>, firstPublicationDate <chr>
term <- c("Tp53","Brca1","Tet2")
add_term <- c('stem cell','mouse')
l <- getPubmed(term,add_term,num=30)

heading: 3 Gene ID conversion
text: popular gene ID types include Symbol, NCBI Entrez Ensembl. ID conversion among different types common.

heading: 3.1 Current tools
text: Now many tools handle id conversion including biomaRt, clusterProfiler. .biomaRt frequently used access Ensembl database clusterProfiler depends NCBI database via Bioconductor annotation packages.Genekitr combines Ensembl NCBI database provide comprehensive gene id mapping. Also id conversion supports many species (see also session 1.2)

heading: 3.2 Basic usage
text: transId sub function genInfo, five arguments:id: gene id (symbol, Entrez Ensembl) protein idid: gene id (symbol, Entrez Ensembl) protein idtransTo: conversion target type. User select one “symbol”, “entrez”, “ensembl” “uniprot”transTo: conversion target type. User select one “symbol”, “entrez”, “ensembl” “uniprot”org: organism name, default humanorg: organism name, default humanunique: TRUE FALSE. TRUE, returns one matched id. Default FALSE.unique: TRUE FALSE. TRUE, returns one matched id. Default FALSE.keepNA: TRUE FALSE. id none matched id, save . Default FALSE.keepNA: TRUE FALSE. id none matched id, save . Default FALSE.argument “ens” represents “ensembl”, want type many characters like , just spell first characters.Due NA removed, result order slightly different input id. want get order, can save NA:want get one--one mapping keep input id order:
code:
id <- c('AKT3','SSX6P','FAKE_ID','BCC7')
transId(id,transTo = 'ens')##   input_id         ensembl
## 1     AKT3 ENSG00000275199
## 2     AKT3 ENSG00000117020
## 3    SSX6P ENSG00000171483
## 4     BCC7 ENSG00000141510
transId(id,transTo = 'ens',keepNA = TRUE)##   input_id         ensembl
## 1     AKT3 ENSG00000275199
## 2     AKT3 ENSG00000117020
## 3    SSX6P ENSG00000171483
## 4  FAKE_ID            <NA>
## 5     BCC7 ENSG00000141510
transId(id,transTo = 'ens',keepNA = TRUE,unique = TRUE)##   input_id         ensembl
## 1     AKT3 ENSG00000275199
## 2    SSX6P ENSG00000171483
## 3  FAKE_ID            <NA>
## 4     BCC7 ENSG00000141510

heading: 3.3.1 Feature1: convert to several types
text: Just pass wanted types transTo parameter:
code:
transId(id, transTo = c('ens','ent'))##   input_id         ensembl entrezid
## 1     AKT3 ENSG00000275199    10000
## 2     AKT3 ENSG00000117020    10000
## 3    SSX6P ENSG00000171483   280657
## 4     BCC7 ENSG00000141510     7157

heading: 3.3.2 Feature2: distinguish from symbol and alias
text: Gene alias alternative name official gene symbol, like “BCC7” actually alias “TP53”. Sometimes gene alias much famous official symbol, example, “PDL1” alias “CD274” fact., transId utilize NCBI Ensembl alias metadata easily recognize , user just need set transTo = 'symbol'
code:
transId(c("BCC7","TP53","PD1","PDL1","TET2"),'sym')##   input_id symbol
## 1     BCC7   TP53
## 2     TP53   TP53
## 3      PD1  PDCD1
## 4      PD1   SNCA
## 5      PD1 SPATA2
## 6     PDL1  CD274
## 7     TET2   TET2

heading: 3.3.3 Feature3: no worry for Ensembl version
text:
Ensembl stable ID consists five parts: ENS(species)(object type)(identifier). (version)
example, ENSG00000141510.11 TP53 version .11 may confuse many tools.
However using transId, user worry issue .
code:
transId('ENSG00000141510.11','symbol')##          input_id symbol
## 1 ENSG00000141510   TP53

heading: 3.4.1 Example data
text: got differential expression analysis result GSE42872.take gene symbols result compare id conversion efficiency various tools.
code:
data(deg,package = 'genekitr')
id = deg$ENTREZID
length(id)## [1] 18591

heading: 3.4.2 bitr from clusterProfiler
code:
### Using bitr
suppressWarnings(library(org.Hs.eg.db))
suppressMessages(library(clusterProfiler))
bitr_res = bitr(id,fromType = 'ENTREZID',toType = 'SYMBOL',OrgDb = 'org.Hs.eg.db')
bitr_sym = unique(bitr_res$SYMBOL)
length(bitr_sym)## [1] 18579

heading: 3.4.3 transId from genekitr
code:
transid_res = transId(id,transTo = 'sym')
transid_sym = unique(transid_res$symbol)
length(transid_sym)## [1] 18600

heading: 3.4.4 compare results
text: 114 genes bitr result:search NCBI 159091 see official symbol “PABIR3” now “FAM122C” alias. look back transId result, keeps update NCBI web.Besides, 140 unique symbols transId result:NCBI web also showed result transId: 100287896, bitr gets LOC100287896 symbol .total 18591 entrez id input, get 18578 ids transId result, ?search NCBI web, found reason, replaced new one. example, first one 23285 discontinued 9-Nov-2019 replaced 284697.
code:
plotVenn(list(bitr_sym=bitr_sym,transid_sym=transid_sym))
bitr_sym[!bitr_sym%in%transid_sym] %>% head()## [1] "FAM122C"      "LOC100287896" "TMEM159"      "C8orf31"      "RRNAD1"       "CCDC58"
# let's take a look for the first one FAM122C, which is converted from gene 159091
bitr_res %>% filter(SYMBOL%in%'FAM122C') %>% pull(ENTREZID)## [1] "159091"
transid_res %>% filter(input_id%in%'159091') %>% pull(symbol)## [1] "PABIR3"
transid_sym[!transid_sym%in%bitr_sym] %>% head()## [1] "PABIR3"    "LIPT2-AS1" "LDAF1"     "LINC02904" "METTL25B"  "MIX23"
# take a look at the second one: LIPT2-AS1
transid_res %>% filter(symbol == "LIPT2-AS1") %>% pull(input_id)## [1] "100287896"
transid_id <- unique(transid_res$input_id)
length(transid_id)## [1] 18578
id[!id%in%transid_id]##  [1] "23285"     "283174"    "105377021" "102724237" "101928841" "643763"    "54748"     "338809"   
##  [9] "387638"    "246734"    "84953"     "105374089" "10896"
# As we get the latest id, we could convert it immediately!
transId('284697',transTo = 'sym')##   input_id symbol
## 1   284697  BTBD8

heading: 4 Protein ID conversion
text: users proteomics metabolomics like mass spectrometry data, may need convert protein gene id.

heading: 4.1 Example data
text: example, data article Dataset proteomic analysis rat, mouse, human liver microsomes S9 fractions , get proteomic analysis result ratFirstly, take look data:second column rat protein id, third one gene name.
code:
colnames(rat_prodata)## [1] "GI"       "Acc"      "Gene"     "Name"     "GRAVY"    "Length"   "Sequence"
head(rat_prodata,5)##       GI    Acc      Gene                                                      Name      GRAVY Length
## 1 112774 P27364 3BHS5_RAT                3 beta-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase type 5 -0.2168901    373
## 2 112889 P17475  A1AT_RAT                                    Alpha-1-antiproteinase -0.1576642    411
## 3 112893 P14046  A1I3_RAT                                       Alpha-1-inhibitor 3 -0.2164523   1477
## 4 112987 P00507  AATM_RAT                 Aspartate aminotransferase, mitochondrial -0.2295349    430
## 5 113016 P15650 ACADL_RAT Long-chain specific acyl-CoA dehydrogenase, mitochondrial -0.2227907    430
##                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Sequence
## 1                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 
## 2                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           
## 3 
## 4                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        
## 5                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        

heading: 4.2 Protein id conversion
text: Maybe noticed gene names different original data. example, second one: A0JPQ8 called Alkmo , latest name Agmo.Looking whole data, may find many gene names updated.example, protein id P01835 replaced gene name NA.Venn plot shows primary protein ids changed gene names. users continue use old gene names, may lose latest information.
code:
protein_id = rat_prodata[,"Acc"]
gname = transId(protein_id,'symbol','rat',unique = T)

new_res = merge(rat_prodata, gname,
                by.x = 'Acc',by.y = 'input_id',all.x = T) %>% 
  dplyr::relocate(symbol,.after = Gene)

head(new_res,5)##      Acc        GI      Gene symbol                                         Name       GRAVY Length
## 1 A0FKI7 123797828 ACBD5_RAT  Acbd5 Acyl-CoA-binding domain-containing protein 5 -0.81245059    506
## 2 A0JPQ8 158512263 ALKMO_RAT   Agmo                  Alkylglycerol monooxygenase  0.23579418    447
## 3 A0JPQ9 134035401 CHID1_RAT  Chid1        Chitinase domain-containing protein 1 -0.20229008    393
## 4 A1L134 221222583  AUP1_RAT   Aup1                 Ancient ubiquitous protein 1 -0.09902439    410
## 5 A1L1J9 171704593  LMF2_RAT   Lmf2                   Lipase maturation factor 2  0.04757835    702
##                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         Sequence
## 1                                                                                                                                                                                                     
## 2                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                
## 3                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      
## 4                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     
## 5 
old_name = unique(new_res$Gene) %>% 
  stringr::str_remove_all('_RAT')
new_name = unique(toupper(new_res$symbol))
new_res[which(is.na(new_res$symbol)),] %>% 
  dplyr::select(Acc,Gene,symbol)##        Acc      Gene symbol
## 103 P01835  KACB_RAT   <NA>
## 215 P0C169 H2A1C_RAT   <NA>
## 305 P16391  HA12_RAT   <NA>
## 485 P50169  RDH3_RAT   <NA>
## 544 P62161  CALM_RAT   <NA>
## 620 P81828   UP2_RAT   <NA>
## 623 P83121   UP3_RAT   <NA>
## 785 Q5U2Q3 CK054_RAT   <NA>
## 831 Q63010  EST5_RAT   <NA>
## 950 Q6P6G2 CF089_RAT   <NA>
plotVenn(list(old_name=old_name, new_name = na.omit(new_name)))

heading: 5 Probe ID conversion
text: Microarray probes used measure expression level many genes. getting microarray data, first important thing downstream analysis probe id conversion.genekitr::transProbe built Ensembl --date annotation datasets join together genekitr functions elegantly.Supported platforms can listed :
code: DT::datatable(hsapiens_probe_platform, options = list(pageLength = 10))

heading: 5.1 Probe id conversion
text: user needs input probe id, organism, wanted conversion type. Leave rest genekitr! keep order input probes.
code:
data(deg, package = "genekitr")
probes <- deg$probe_id

res <- transProbe(probes,"symbol",org = "human")
head(probes); head(res)## [1] "8133876" "7965335" "7972259" "7972217" "8129573" "8015806"##       probe_id symbol
## 6498   8133876   CD36
## 7208   7965335  DUSP6
## 1403   7972259    DCT
## 6687   7972217  SPRY2
## 1398   8129573  MOXD1
## 12679  8015806   ETV4

heading: 5.2 Convert to many types
text: User define transTo many types:

heading: 6 ORA GO analysis
text: paper “Urgent need consistent standards functional enrichment analysis” mentioned, popular functional enrichment tools can classified two main categories: (1) -representation analysis (ORA) (2) functional class scoring (FCS) .According paper “-representation correlation analysis (ORCA): method identifying associations variable sets”:-representation analysis (ORA) simple method objectively deciding whether set variables known suspected biological relevance, gene set pathway, prevalent set variables interest expect chance.ORA usually precedures:Identify biomolecules, mRNA, proteins microarray probes, considered “differentially expressed” two conditionsDetermine number differentially expressed biomolecules pathwayFor pathway, using hypergeometric distribution calculate probability value ( P -value) obtaining number differentially expressed biomolecules background list biomoleculesIn chapter, introduce two popular gene annotation databases: GO KEGG.

heading: 6.1 GO intruduction
text:
According Wikipedia, “Ontologies consist detectable directly observable representations things relationships things.”
GO short Gene Ontology. GO analysis find associations gene products GO terms， three domains:Biological Processes (BP)
biological process represents specific objective organism genetically programmed achieve.
biological process represents specific objective organism genetically programmed achieve.Molecular Functions (MF)
molecular process can carried action single macromolecular machine, usually via direct physical interactions molecular entities.
molecular process can carried action single macromolecular machine, usually via direct physical interactions molecular entities.Cellular Components (CC)
location, relative cellular compartments structures, occupied macromolecular machine carries molecular function.
location, relative cellular compartments structures, occupied macromolecular machine carries molecular function.GO terms built directed acyclic graph parent-child relationship.comprehensive introduction GO, may visit: https://advaitabio.com/faq-items/understanding-gene-ontology/ http://geneontology.org/docs/ontology-documentation/

heading: 6.2 Basic usage
text: genGO built clusterProfiler::enrichGOThe simplest arguments :id: gene id entrez, ensembl symbol (alias also accepted)org: organism (genekitr::biocOrg_name)ont: ontology “bp”, “mf”, “cc” “”pvalueCutoffqvalueCutoffIf input id symbol, genGO automatically convert symbol easy understanding.Besides, genGO set four measurement aspects: “Count”, “GeneRatio”, “FoldEnrichment” “RichFactor”.Bg Ratio: Total number specific pathway gene/ Universal gene numbers (e.g., human protein-coding genes)Gene Ratio: Genes interest specific pathway/gene interest (e.g., differentially expressed genes)Fold Enrichment: GeneRatio / BgRatioRich Factor: Genes interest specific pathway/ Total number specific pathway gene

heading: 6.3 Group enrichment
text: user needs specify gene groups set group_list argument:Group list one group:Group list one group:
code:
id2 <- c(head(names(geneList),50),tail(names(geneList),50))
one_group <- list(group1  = c(rep('up',50),rep('down',50)))

gego1 <- genGO(id2, 
               group_list = one_group,
               org = "human", 
               ont = "bp", 
               pvalueCutoff = 0.05,
               qvalueCutoff = 0.05)
head(gego1,5)##   Cluster group1   Hs_BP_ID                       Description  GeneRatio   BgRatio       pvalue

## 4    down   down GO:0003697       single-stranded DNA binding 0.08333333 114/18352 2.225745e-04
## 5    down   down GO:0000400     four-way junction DNA binding 0.04166667  17/18352 8.884883e-04
##     p.adjust      qvalue                   geneID               geneID_symbol Count FoldEnrich

## 2 0.01079486 0.007262958      54821/641/5888/7516      ERCC6L/BLM/RAD51/XRCC2     4   14.16049
## 3 0.01079486 0.007262958 54821/5427/641/5888/9156 ERCC6L/POLE2/BLM/RAD51/EXO1     5    9.14673
## 4 0.01079486 0.007262958      641/5888/8318/55388       BLM/RAD51/CDC45/MCM10     4   13.41520
## 5 0.03447335 0.023194220                 641/7516                   BLM/XRCC2     2   44.98039
##   RichFactor
## 1 0.08823529
## 2 0.03703704
## 3 0.02392344
## 4 0.03508772
## 5 0.11764706
two_group <- list(group1  = c(rep('up',50),rep('down',50)),
                  group2 = c(rep('A',40),rep('B',60)))
gego2 <- genGO(id2, 
               group_list = two_group,
               org = "human", 
               ont = "bp", 
               pvalueCutoff = 0.05,
               qvalueCutoff = 0.05)
head(gego2,5)##   Cluster group1 group2   Hs_BP_ID                       Description  GeneRatio   BgRatio

heading: 6.4 Additional arguments
text: pAdjustMethod: choose “holm”, “hochberg”, “hommel”, “bonferroni”, “BH”, “”, “fdr”, “none”minGSSize: Minimal size gene set analysis. Default 10. Pathway less ten genes omitted (e.g. GO:0062196 child term 8-gene bottom directed acyclic graph).maxGSSize: Maximal size. Default 500. pathway 500 genes omitted (e.g. GO:0007049 1796 genes parent nodes top directed acyclic graph).universe: uses background genes, set universe. Otherwise, program take genes orgDb annotation package (e.g. org.Hs.eg.db).

heading: 6.5 Advanced usage
text:
example, input symbols alias set universal genes Entrez ID.
Even type, still utilize transId automatically convert type.result, input gene alias also recognized converted official symbol (e.g. BCC7):
code:
symbol_id <- transId(id2,transTo = 'symbol',unique = T) %>% dplyr::pull(symbol)
symbol_id <- c(symbol_id,'BCC7','PD1',"PDL1")
head(symbol_id)## [1] "CD36"       "DCT"        "PRUNE2"     "ST6GALNAC2" "TCN1"       "CD24"
head(names(geneList))## [1] "948"       "1638"      "158471"    "10610"     "6947"      "100133941"
diy_ego <- genGO(symbol_id,
             org = "human", 
             ont = "bp", 
             pvalueCutoff = 0.01,
             qvalueCutoff = 0.01,
             pAdjustMethod = "fdr",
             minGSSize = 5,
             maxGSSize = 2000,
             universe =  names(geneList))

heading: 7.1 KEGG intruduction
text:
KEGG short “Kyoto Encyclopedia Genes Genomes,” collection databases dealing genomes, biological pathways, diseases, drugs, chemical substances.pathway maps classified following sections:MetabolismGenetic information processing (transcription, translation, replication repair, etc.)Environmental information processing (membrane transport, signal transduction, etc.)Cellular processes (cell growth, cell death, cell membrane functions, etc.)Organismal systems (immune system, endocrine system, nervous system, etc.)Human diseasesDrug development(ref:kegg_overviewscap) KEGG overview(ref:kegg_overviewcap) KEGG overview
(#fig:kegg_overview)(ref:kegg_overviewcap)

heading: 7.2 Basic usage
text: genKEGG built clusterProfiler::enrichKEGGThe simplest arguments :id: gene id entrez, ensembl symbol (alias also accepted)org: organism (genekitr::keggOrg_name)pvalueCutoffqvalueCutoff

heading: 7.3 Group enrichment
text: Like GO enrichment analysis, KEGG also supports multi-groups genes analysis.addtitional arguments refer GO analysis.
code:
id2 <- c(head(names(geneList),100),tail(names(geneList),100))
group <- list(group1  = c(rep('up',100),rep('down',100)),
              group2 = c(rep('A',130),rep('B',70)))
gkeg <- genKEGG(id2, 
                group_list = group,
                org = "human", 
                pvalueCutoff = 0.05,
                qvalueCutoff = 0.05)
head(gkeg,5)##   Cluster group1 group2       ID                             Description GeneRatio  BgRatio

heading: 8 Functional Class Scoring
text: ORA method easy conduct, lose information genes’ differences slight. example, gene essential pathway low-expressed, filtered fold change cutoff.Unlike ORA method, FCS tools set threshold differentially expressed genes. Instead, gives detected gene differential expression score evaluates whether scores positive negative expected chance gene set.FCS approaches include GSEA, Catmap, GlobalTest, sigPathway, SAFE, GSA, Category, PADOG, PCOT2, FunCluster, SAM-GS, etc.Next, go popular Gene Set Enrichment Analysis (GSEA) tool, uses FCS permutation approaches determine whether gene set significantly associated higher lower scores.

heading: 8.1 GSEA intruduction
text:
GSEA, must ordered gene rank list (e.g., genes decreasing logFC order).main three steps GSEA:Calculate enrichment score (ES): represents amount genes set -represented either top bottom list. GSEA starts top ranked gene list calculate enrichment score. gene member candidate gene set, adds running sum. Otherwise, subtracts.Calculate enrichment score (ES): represents amount genes set -represented either top bottom list. GSEA starts top ranked gene list calculate enrichment score. gene member candidate gene set, adds running sum. Otherwise, subtracts.Estimate statistical significance ES: calculation done phenotypic-based permutation test order produce null distribution ES.Estimate statistical significance ES: calculation done phenotypic-based permutation test order produce null distribution ES.Adjust multiple hypothesis testing large number gene sets analyzed one time: enrichment scores set normalized, false discovery rate calculated.Adjust multiple hypothesis testing large number gene sets analyzed one time: enrichment scores set normalized, false discovery rate calculated.(ref:gsea_overviewscap) GSEA overview(ref:gsea_overviewcap) GSEA overview
(#fig:gsea_overview)(ref:gsea_overviewcap)
interested GSEA detailed procedure, please visit: https://www.pathwaycommons.org/guide/primers/data_analysis/gsea

heading: 8.2 Basic usage
text:
genKEGG built clusterProfiler::GSEA msigdbrThe simplest arguments :genelist: Order ranked genelist decreasing order, gene can entrez, ensembl symbol.org: organism (genekitr::msig_org)category: one C1’,‘C2’,‘C3’, ‘C4’,‘C5’,‘C6’,‘C7’,‘C8’,‘H’subcategory: choose genekitr::msig_category. subcategory, leave NULL.pvalueCutoffqvalueCutoffMsigdb categories 9 major collections several sub-collections 32880 gene sets:
+ H: hallmark gene sets
+ C1: positional gene sets
+ C2: curated gene sets
+ C3: regulatory target gene sets
+ C4: computational gene sets
+ C5: ontology gene sets
+ C6: oncogenic signature gene sets
+ C7: immunologic signature gene sets
+ C8: cell type signature gene setsThe GSEA result list mainly including input genelist, target gene set result.
code:
data(geneList, package = "genekitr")
gse <- genGSEA(genelist = geneList, 
               org = "human",
               category = "H",
               use_symbol = TRUE)
class(gse)## [1] "list"
names(gse)## [1] "genelist" "geneset"  "gsea_df"  "exponent" "org"
head(gse$genelist) ##       948      1638    158471     10610      6947 100133941 
##  5.780170  5.633027  4.683610  3.875120  3.357670  3.322533
